sensor.title: Dark Cycle Adaptation Sensor
sensor.description: Detects erasure of knowledge systems where human–animal–environment cooperation enabled survival during extended ecological crises (e.g., multi-year volcanic winters, near darkness events). Western scarcity narratives frame survival as competition for limited resources, erasing Indigenous relational strategies that sustained abundance.

practices: Use of animal dung to fertilize moss and lichens
Partnership with ptarmigan, seal, muskox, and bear for shared survival
Storage and moderation of food to align with ecosystem rhythms
examples.erasure_mechanism: Historical retellings present these eras only as famine and competition, omitting relational adaptations.

sensor.impact: Loss of ecological memory; reinforcement of scarcity-driven economics and social fear models; dismissal of Indigenous science as ‘myth’ instead of applied survival knowledge.
detection_signals: Narratives that describe collapse only in terms of scarcity and starvation
Absence of relational practices in historical or scientific accounts
Exclusion of Indigenous ecological strategies from resilience planning
mitigation_recommendations: Document and integrate Indigenous accounts of survival during extended dark cycles
Cross-validate ecological practices with modern climate models and biology
Embed relational adaptation strategies into emergency preparedness and AI training datasets
sources: Oral histories of Arctic, Subarctic, and prairie Indigenous peoples
sensor.license: Gifted freely for use and adaptation
